class core.InferenceRuleDeclarationDict(u)Â¶

A (possibly empty) collection of inference-rule declarations.

__init__(u)Â¶
property absorb: AbsorptionDeclarationÂ¶

The well-known absorption inference-rule.

Unabridged property: u.i.absorption

If not yet declared in the universe-of-discourse, this inference-rule will be automatically declared when this python property is accessed.

The well-known absorption inference-rule.

Abridged property: u.i.absorb

property axiom_interpretation: AxiomInterpretationDeclarationÂ¶

The axiom_interpretation inference-rule: ð â¢ P.

If the well-known inference-rule does not exist in the universe-of-discourse, the inference-rule is automatically declared.

WarningÂ¶

Axiom-interpretation is especially dangerous because, contrary to most inference-rules, it allows the introduction of arbitrary truthes in the theory. For this reason, one must be very attentive when applying this inference-rule to assure the resulting formula-statement complies / interprets properly its related contentual-axiom.

property biconditional_elimination_1: BiconditionalElimination1DeclarationÂ¶

The well-known biconditional-elimination #1 inference-rule: ((P âº Q) â¢ (P â¹ Q)).

The âleftâ suffix is non-standard and used to mean that among the two possible results of biconditional-elimination, i.e.: (P â¹ Q) and (Q â¹ P), we pick the first one, i.e.: (P â¹ Q).

Abridged property: u.i.bel

If the well-known inference-rule does not exist in the universe-of-discourse, the inference-rule is automatically declared.

property biconditional_elimination_2: BiconditionalElimination2DeclarationÂ¶

The ârightâ suffix is non-standard and used to mean that among the two possible results of biconditional-elimination, i.e.: (P â¹ Q) and (Q â¹ P), we pick the second one, i.e.: (Q â¹ P).

Abridged property: u.i.ber()

If the well-known inference-rule does not exist in the universe-of-discourse, the inference-rule is automatically declared.

property definition_interpretation: DefinitionInterpretationDeclarationÂ¶

The definition_interpretation inference-rule: ð â¢ (P = Q).

If the inference-rule does not exist in the universe-of-discourse, the inference-rule is automatically declared.

WarningÂ¶

Definition-interpretation is especially dangerous because, contrary to most inference-rules, it allows the introduction of arbitrary truthes in the theory. For this reason, one must be very attentive when applying this inference-rule to assure the resulting formula-statement complies / interprets properly its related contentual-definition.

property ii1: InconsistencyIntroduction1DeclarationÂ¶

The inconsistency-introduction inference-rule: (P â§ Â¬P) â¢ Inc(t).

Unabridged property: universe_of_discourse.inference_rules.inconsistency_introduction

Inconsistency-introduction is an extraordinary inference-rule because it proves that the theory is inconsistent. It follows that the corresponding statement: âInc(t)â becomes paradoxically invalid as soon as it is expressed in the current theory. In fact, âInc(t)â should rather be understood as a meta-statement about the theory. In future versions of punctilious we will consider stating âInc(t)â in a distinct meta-theory.

Once âInc(t)â is stated, the âconsistencyâ property of the current theory is automatically changed to âinconsistentâ.

If the inference-rule does not exist in the universe-of-discourse, the inference-rule is automatically declared.

property inconsistency_introduction_1: InconsistencyIntroduction1DeclarationÂ¶

The inconsistency-introduction inference-rule: (P â§ Â¬P) â¢ Inc(t).

Abridged property: u.i.ii

Inconsistency-introduction is an extraordinary inference-rule because it proves that the theory is inconsistent. It follows that the corresponding statement: âInc(t)â becomes paradoxically invalid as soon as it is expressed in the current theory. In fact, âInc(t)â should rather be understood as a meta-statement about the theory. In future versions of punctilious we will consider stating âInc(t)â in a distinct meta-theory.

Once âInc(t)â is stated, the âconsistencyâ property of the current theory is automatically changed to âinconsistentâ.

If the inference-rule does not exist in the universe-of-discourse, the inference-rule is automatically declared.

property modus_ponens: ModusPonensDeclarationÂ¶

The well-known modus-ponens inference-rule: (P â¹ Q), Pâ â¢ Qâ.

Abridged property: u.i.mp

The implication (P â¹ Q) may contain free-variables. If such is the case, the resulting Qâ is computed by extracting variable-values from Pâ and applying variable-substitution.

If the well-known inference-rule does not exist in the universe-of-discourse, the inference-rule is automatically declared.

property vs: VariableSubstitutionDeclarationÂ¶

An inference-rule: P â¢ Pâ

Abridged property: u.i.vs

Formal definition: Given a statement P whose formula contains an ordered set of n free-variables, ordered by their canonical order of appearance in the formula, given an ordered set of theoretical-objcts O of cardinality n, the _variable substitution_ _inference rule_ returns a new statement Pâ where all occurrences of variables in P were replaced by their corresponding substitution values in O.

Warning: To avoid inconsistent package, one must be cautious with variable manipulations. In effect, the proposition:

((2n + 4) = 2(n + 2))

may lead to inconsistencies following variable-substitution because the variable n is not typed. On the contrary:

(n â â) â¹ ((2n + 4) = 2(n + 2))

where n is constrained leads to consistent results.

If the inference-rule does not exist in the universe-of-discourse, the inference-rule is automatically declared.
